etymology.description: Pictogram: an upside-down human figure (大 inverted), with a later horizontal stroke in small seal script; original form of 逆.
etymology.interpretation: An inverted person conveys the idea of going against the normal orientation, hence “opposite” or “contrary.” The extra horizontal stroke in small seal script visually underscores the inversion and reinforces the sense of reversal later carried by 逆.

examples.chinese: 古文字中，屰是逆的本字(古文字中，屰是逆的本字)。
examples.pinyin: Gǔ wénzì zhōng, nì shì nì de běnzì.
examples.english: In ancient script, 屰 is the original form of 逆.

examples.chinese: 小篆写法多了一横，强调人倒了过来(小篆寫法多了一橫，強調人倒了過來)。
examples.pinyin: Xiǎozhuàn xiěfǎ duō le yì héng, qiángdiào rén dǎo le guòlái.
examples.english: In small seal script an extra horizontal stroke was added, emphasizing that the person is upside down.

examples.chinese: 学者在讨论字形时常用屰表示“相反”的概念(學者在討論字形時常用屰表示「相反」的概念)。
examples.pinyin: Xuézhě zài tǎolùn zìxíng shí cháng yòng nì biǎoshì “xiāngfǎn” de gàiniàn.
examples.english: Scholars often use 屰 to represent the concept of “opposite” when discussing glyph forms.
